1.brief: tender (literally or figuratively); by implication, weak
to turn back (hence, away) transitively or intransitively, literally or figuratively (not necessarily with the idea of return to the starting point); generally to retreat; often adverbial, again
heat; figuratively, anger, poison (from its fever)
a word; by implication, a matter (as spoken of) or thing; adverbially, a cause
an earthen vessel; usually (painful) toil; also a pang (whether of body or mind)
to ascend, intransitively (be high) or actively (mount); used in a great variety of senses, primary and secondary, literal and figurative
properly, the nose or nostril; hence, the face, and occasionally a person; also (from the rapid breathing in passion) ire

2.brief: the tongue (of man or animals), used literally (as the instrument of licking, eating, or speech), and figuratively (speech, an ingot, a fork of flame, a cove of water)
to be (causative) make well, literally (sound, beautiful) or figuratively (happy, successful, right)
the mouth (as the means of blowing), whether literal or figurative (particularly speech); specifically edge, portion or side; adverbially (with preposition) according to
properly, fat, i.e. (figuratively) stupid or silly
to gush forth; figuratively, to utter (good or bad words); specifically, to emit (a foul odor)

3.brief: properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
properly, a standing, i.e. a spot; but used widely of a locality (general or specific); also (figuratively) of a condition (of body or mind)
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
properly, to lean forward, i.e. to peer into the distance; by implication, to observe, await
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)

4.brief: properly, curative, i.e. literally (concretely) a medicine, or (abstractly) a cure; figuratively (concretely) deliverance, or (abstractly) placidity
the tongue (of man or animals), used literally (as the instrument of licking, eating, or speech), and figuratively (speech, an ingot, a fork of flame, a cove of water)
a tree (from its firmness); hence, wood (plural sticks)
alive; hence, raw (flesh); fresh (plant, water, year), strong; also (as noun, especially in the feminine singular and masculine plural) life (or living thing), whether literally or figuratively
a fracture, figuratively, ruin; specifically, a solution (of a dream)

wind; by resemblance breath, i.e. a sensible (or even violent) exhalation; figuratively, life, anger, unsubstantiality; by extension, a region of the sky; by resemblance spirit, but only of a rational being (including its expression and functions)

5.brief: properly, chastisement; figuratively, reproof, warning or instruction; also restraint
father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
chastisement; figuratively (by words) correction, refutation, proof (even in defence)
properly, to be (or make) bare; but used only in the derivative sense (through the idea perhaps of smoothness) to be cunning (usually in a bad sense)

6.brief: a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)
abundant (in quantity, size, age, number, rank, quality)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
properly, to roil water; figuratively, to disturb or affict

7.brief: the lip (as a natural boundary); by implication, language; by analogy, a margin (of a vessel, water, cloth, etc.)
to toss about; by implication, to diffuse, winnow
the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
properly, fat, i.e. (figuratively) stupid or silly
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, set upright; hence (figuratively as adjective) just; but usually (as adverb or conjunction) rightly or so (in various applications to manner, time and relation; often with other particles)

8.brief: properly, a slaughter, i.e. the flesh of an animal; by implication, a sacrifice (the victim or the act)
morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
properly, something disgusting (morally), i.e. (as noun) an abhorrence; especially idolatry or (concretely) an idol
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
intercession, supplication; by implication, a hymn

morally wrong; concretely, an (actively) bad person
to run after (usually with hostile intent; figuratively (of time) gone by)
rightness (abstractly), subjectively (rectitude), objectively (justice), morally (virtue) or figuratively (prosperity)
to have affection for (sexually or otherwise)

bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)

chastisement; figuratively (by words) correction, refutation, proof (even in defence)
to die (literally or figuratively); causatively, to kill

a front, i.e. part opposite; specifically a counterpart, or mate; usually (adverbial, especially with preposition) over against or before
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
meaning accession (used as an adverb or conjunction); also or yea; adversatively though
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed

ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)

to have affection for (sexually or otherwise)
properly, to make mouths at, i.e. to scoff; hence (from the effort to pronounce a foreign language) to interpret, or (generally) intercede
to be right (i.e. correct); reciprocal, to argue; causatively, to decide, justify or convict
near, with or among; often in general, to
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)

to search out (by any method, specifically in worship or prayer); by implication, to strive after

a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)

drink, by implication, drinking (the act); also (by implication) a banquet or (generally) feast

16.brief: good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)

there (transferring to time) then; often thither, or thence

heat; figuratively, anger, poison (from its fever)
properly, to grate, i.e. (figuratively) to anger
properly, the nose or nostril; hence, the face, and occasionally a person; also (from the rapid breathing in passion) ire

a well-trodden road (literally or figuratively); also a caravan
to mound up (especially a turnpike); figurative, to exalt; reflexively, to oppose (as by a dam)

20.brief: a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)

father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application

ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)

a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
intelligence; by implication, an argument; by extension, caprice
to be straight or even; figuratively, to be (causatively, to make) right, pleasant, prosperous
to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)
